contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = ''Acanthosaura'' | image = Acanthosaura1.JPG | image_caption = Mountain Horned Dragon, ''Acanthosaura sp.'' | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Reptile|Reptilia]] | ordo = [[Squamata]] | subordo = [[Lacertilia]] | familia = [[Agamidae]] | subfamilia = [[Agaminae]] | genus = '''''Acanthosaura''''' | genus_authority = [[John Edward Gray|Gray]], 1831 }} '''Acanthosaura''' is a [[genus]] of [[lizard]]s commonly known as '''mountain horned dragons''', or '''pricklenape agamas'''. They are so named because of a row of dorsal spines which run down the back of their neck. They are arboreal lizards that are found in [[Southeast Asia]]. They are medium-sized, ranging from about 7½ inches up to 15 inches in length, depending on species and individual. They tend to prefer higher elevation areas that are dense with vegetation. ==Diet== Mountain horned dragons are [[insectivore|insectivorous]], consuming only live food. Common feeders in captivity include crickets, earthworms, silkworms, mealworms, moths, roaches, wax worms, and grasshoppers. Mountain Horned Dragons require a variety in diet and will often refuse food when offered in excessive redundancy. Typical Acanthosaura feeding behavior is a sit-and-wait style. They will perch 1 to 2 meters off the ground until they spot their prey, which is often down on the ground. It isn't uncommon to see a spectacular display of aerobatics from Acanthosaura species when hunting food. Mountain Horned Dragons will eat and hunt fish, but most won't submerge their heads to catch a meal. ==Reproduction== Females lay their first clutch of [[egg (biology)|eggs]] about 4 months after mating. They may lay up to 4 clutches total per year, separated by a month or two. ==In captivity== [[Image:Acanthosaura2.JPG|thumb|right|Acanthosaura capra at [[Chester Zoo]]]] Mountain horned dragons are popular pets, and readily available in the exotic pet trade. ''A. capra'' is considered the hardiest and most easily-kept species of the genus, and is the most common species found for sale in the [[United States]]. While not considered to be difficult to breed in captivity, most specimens available are wild caught. ==Species== * ''[[Acanthosaura armata]]'', Armored Pricklenape ([[John Edward Gray|Gray]], 1827) - [[China]], [[Burma]], [[Thailand]], [[Malaysia]] and [[Indonesia]]. * ''[[Acanthosaura bintangensis]]'' Wood Jr., Grismer, Lee Grismer, Ahmad, Onn & Bauer, 2009 - [[Perak]], [[Peninsular Malaysia]] *''[[Acanthosaura brachypoda]]'' Ananjeva, Orlov, Nguyen, and Ryabov, 2011 - [[Vietnam]] * ''[[Acanthosaura capra]]'', Green Pricklenape ([[Albert C. L. G. Günther|Günther]], 1861) - [[Cambodia]], [[Laos]], and [[Vietnam]]. * ''[[Acanthosaura cardamomensis]]'' Wood Jr., Grismer, Lee Grismer, Neang, Chav & Holden, 2010<ref>http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/z02488p038f.pdf</ref> - eastern [[Thailand]] and western [[Cambodia]]. * ''[[Acanthosaura coronata]]'' Günther, 1861 - [[Vietnam]] * ''[[Acanthosaura crucigera]]'', Boulenger's Pricklenape ([[George Albert Boulenger|Boulenger]], 1885) - Burma, Thailand, C Vietnam, Malaysia, and Cambodia. * ''[[Acanthosaura lepidogaster]]'', Brown Pricklenape ([[Georges Cuvier|Cuvier]], 1829) - Thailand, Vietnam, Cambodia, Burma, and China. * ''[[Acanthosaura nataliae]]'' Orlov, Nguyen & Nguyen, 2006 - [[Vietnam]] * ''[[Acanthosaura titiwangsaensis]]'' Wood Jr., Grismer, Lee Grismer, Ahmad, Onn & Bauer, 2009 - [[Fraser's Hill]] and [[Cameron Highlands]], [[Pahang]], [[Peninsular Malaysia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.froggieb.com/MHDCaresheet.html Captive Care of Mountain Horned Dragons] [[Category:Agamidae]] [[Category:Reptiles of Asia]] {{agamidae-stub}}
